title: Joe Biden
added: Before naming any White House staff or cabinet appointments, Biden announced that he will appoint [[COVID-19 Advisory Board|a COVID-19 task force]], co-chaired by former Surgeon General [[Vivek Murthy]], former Food and Drug Administration Commissioner [[David A. Kessler|David Kessler]] and Yale University epidemiologist Professor [[Marcella Nunez-Smith]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Feuer|first=Will|date=2020-11-07|title=President-elect Joe Biden to announce Covid task force on Monday|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/07/president-elect-joe-biden-to-announce-covid-task-force-on-monday.html|access-date=2020-11-08|website=CNBC|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Mercia|first=Dan|last2=Zeleny|first2=Jeff|date=November 7, 2020|title=Biden to announce coronavirus task force as part of presidential transition|work=[[CNN]]|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/07/politics/transition-biden-coronavirus-task-force/index.html|url-status=live|access-date=November 9, 2020}}</ref> Biden pledged a larger federal government response to [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States|the pandemic]] than Donald Trump, akin to President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]]'s [[New Deal]] following the [[Great Depression]].<ref name="GoodStol">{{cite news |last1=Goodnough |first1=Abby |last2=Stolberg |first2=Sheryl Gay |title=Biden’s Covid Response Plan Draws From F.D.R.’s New Deal |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/14/health/covid-biden-pandemic-plan.html |accessdate=7 November 2020 |work=The New York Times |date=15 October 2020}}</ref> This would include increased testing for the COVID virus, a steady supply of [[personal protective equipment]], distributing a vaccine and securing money from Congress for schools and hospitals under the aegis of a national "supply chain commander" who would coordinate the logistics of manufacturing and distributing protective gear and test kits. This would be distributed by a "Pandemic Testing Board", also similar to Roosevelt's [[War Production Board]].<ref name="GoodStol" /> Biden also pledged to invoke the [[Defense Production Act]] more aggressively than Trump in order to build up supplies, as well as the mobilization of up to 100,000 Americans for a "public health jobs corps" of [[Contact tracing|contact tracers]] to help track and prevent outbreaks.<ref name="GoodStol" /> "Other members are Dr. [[Luciana Borio]], [[Rick Bright]], Dr. [[Ezekiel Emanuel]], Dr. [[Atul Gawande]], Dr. [[Celine Gounder]], Dr. [[Julie Morita]], [[Michael Osterholm]], [[Loyce Pace]], Dr. Robert Rodriguez and Dr. [[Eric Goosby]]."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Christensen|first=Jen|title=How Biden plans to change the US pandemic response|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/08/health/biden-pandemic-plan/index.html|access-date=2020-11-09|website=CNN}}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
added: In 1999, he supported [[NATO]] airstrikes on [[Serbia]]. As chairman of the US Senate Foreign Affairs Committee, he declared on October 10, 2002, that [[Iraq]] possessed weapons of mass destruction. In October 2002, Biden voted for the [[Iraq War|war in Iraq]].

In October 2014, he accused [[Turkey]], [[Saudi Arabia]] and the [[United Arab Emirates]] of supporting the terrorist organizations [[Al-Nusra Front]] and [[al-Qaeda]] and other [[jihad]]ist radicals flowing into [[Syria]] from around the world in the fight against the Syrian government. Turkish President [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] demanded an apology from Biden, saying that if he did not apologize, Biden would be a thing of the past. Biden, who described Erdoğan as his "old friend", subsequently apologized to Erdoğan. Two years later, he called the Kurdish Party of the PKK, which is fighting against Turkey for the creation of an independent [[Kurds|Kurdish]] state, a "terrorist organization." As a presidential candidate in September 2020, he called on Turkey not to join the [[Nagorno-Karabakh war]].

Joe Biden's son [[Hunter Biden]] was shortly after [[euromaidan]] in [[Ukraine]] in 2014 accepted as a member of the Board of Directors of the Ukrainian [[gas]] companies. The company was investigated on suspicion of corruption in Ukraine and the United Kingdom, and the then Ukrainian Prosecutor General, who was investigating the corruption, was removed from office after alleged pressure from Vice President Biden and Foreign Minister [[John Kerry]] on the government of President [[Petro Poroshenko]] to clean up the prosecutor's office. The investigation was later stopped by a British court due to a lack of evidence.
He would leave the US Embassy in [[Israel]] in [[Jerusalem]], where it was moved under the Trump administration. According to Biden, the United States could renew its nuclear deal with [[Iran]].

In 2000, as a senator, he supported [[China]]'s accession to the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO) and its opening to the international market. It would abolish unilateral tariffs on China. In December 2013, his son Hunter, a co-founder of BHR Partners, a state-owned China-American investment firm with the support of the state-owned Bank of China and investing in many China-US projects, flew to China on an official visit in [[Air Force Two]] government plane with Joe Biden. In this context, some critics have pointed to a possible conflict of interest. In May 2019, he faced criticism from both Republicans and some Democrats, declaring that China did not pose a threat and competition to the United States.

title: Joe Biden
added: In 1999, he supported [[NATO]] airstrikes on [[Serbia]]. As chairman of the US Senate Foreign Affairs Committee, he declared on October 10, 2002, that [[Iraq]] possessed weapons of mass destruction. In October 2002, Biden voted for the [[Iraq War|war in Iraq]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Fact check: Did Biden support wars in Iraq, Serbia, Syria and Libya? : |url=https://www.wral.com/fact-check-did-biden-support-wars-in-iraq-serbia-syria-and-libya/19257083/ |website=WRAL.com |language=en |date=27 August 2020}}</ref>

In October 2014, he accused [[Turkey]], [[Saudi Arabia]] and the [[United Arab Emirates]] of supporting the terrorist organizations [[Al-Nusra Front]] and [[al-Qaeda]] and other [[jihad]]ist radicals flowing into [[Syria]] from around the world in the fight against the Syrian government. Turkish President [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] demanded an apology from Biden, saying that if he did not apologize, Biden would be a thing of the past. Biden, who described Erdoğan as his "old friend", subsequently apologized to Erdoğan.<ref>{{cite news |title=Joe Biden apologised over IS remarks, but was he right? |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-29528482 |work=BBC News |date=7 October 2014}}</ref> Two years later, he called the Kurdish Party of the PKK, which is fighting against Turkey for the creation of an independent [[Kurds|Kurdish]] state, a "terrorist organization." As a presidential candidate in September 2020, he called on Turkey not to join the [[Nagorno-Karabakh war]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Biden calls on Turkey to stay away from Nagorno-Karabakh conflict |url=https://ahvalnews.com/nagorno-karabakh/biden-calls-turkey-stay-away-nagorno-karabakh-conflict-blog-sept-29 |work=Ahvalnews.com |language=en}}</ref>

Joe Biden's son [[Hunter Biden]] was shortly after [[euromaidan]] in [[Ukraine]] in 2014 accepted as a member of the Board of Directors of the Ukrainian [[gas]] companies. The company was investigated on suspicion of corruption in Ukraine and the United Kingdom, and the then Ukrainian Prosecutor General, who was investigating the corruption, was removed from office after alleged pressure from Vice President Biden and Foreign Minister [[John Kerry]] on the government of President [[Petro Poroshenko]] to clean up the prosecutor's office.<ref>{{cite news |title=What Hunter Biden did on the board of Ukrainian energy company Burisma |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hunter-biden-ukraine-idUSKBN1WX1P7 |work=Reuters |date=19 October 2019 |language=en}}</ref> The investigation was later stopped by a British court due to a lack of evidence.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ukrainian prosecutors find no evidence against Hunter Biden |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/jun/04/ukranian-prosecutors-finds-no-evidence-against-hunter-biden |work=The Guardian |date=4 June 2020}}</ref>

He would leave the US Embassy in [[Israel]] in [[Jerusalem]], where it was moved under the Trump administration.<ref>{{cite news |title=Biden says he’d leave US embassy in Jerusalem if elected |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/04/29/biden-says-hed-leave-us-embassy-in-jerusalem-if-elected/ |work=www.aljazeera.com |language=en}}</ref> According to Biden, the United States could renew its nuclear deal with [[Iran]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Biden will seek to reenter Iran nuclear deal within months, former aide says |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/biden-will-seek-to-reenter-iran-nuclear-deal-within-months-aide-says/ |work=www.timesofisrael.com}}</ref>

In 2000, as a senator, he supported [[China]]'s accession to the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO) and its opening to the international market.<ref>{{cite news |title=True: Biden supported China’s entry into the World Trade Organization. |url=https://www.logically.ai/factchecks/library/66061abf |work=Logically.ai |language=en-gb}}</ref> He would abolish unilateral tariffs on China.<ref>{{cite news |title=Biden Says He Will End Trump’s Tariffs On Chinese-Made Goods, Aide Walks Back Statement |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/stuartanderson/2020/08/06/biden-says-he-will-end-trumps-tariffs-on-chinese-made-goods/?sh=2ff1967e523a |work=Forbes |language=en}}</ref> In December 2013, his son Hunter, a co-founder of BHR Partners, a state-owned China-American investment firm with the support of the state-owned Bank of China and investing in many China-US projects, flew to China on an official visit in [[Air Force Two]] government plane with Joe Biden. In this context, some critics have pointed to a possible conflict of interest.<ref>{{cite news |title=What We Know About Hunter Biden’s Dealings in China |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/what-we-know-about-hunter-bidens-dealings-in-china-11570181403 |work=Wall Street Journal |date=4 October 2019}}</ref> In May 2019, he faced criticism from both Republicans and some Democrats, declaring that China did not pose a threat and competition to the United States.<ref>{{cite news |title=Biden's comments downplaying China threat to U.S. fire up pols on both sides |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/biden-s-comments-downplaying-china-threat-u-s-fires-pols-n1001236 |work=NBC News |language=en}}</ref>

title: Joe Biden
deleted: After his nomination, the Catholic bishop of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Scranton|Scranton, Pennsylvania]], barred Biden from receiving [[Holy Communion]] there because of his support for abortion rights,<ref>{{cite news |first=David |last=Kirkpatrick |title=Abortion Issue Again Dividing Catholic Votes |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/17/us/politics/17catholics.html |work=The New York Times |date=September 16, 2008 |accessdate=September 19, 2008 }}</ref> but Biden continued to receive Communion at his Delaware parish.<ref name="ce082808">{{cite news |url=https://catholicexchange.com/bidens-bishop-will-not-permit-him-even-if-elected-vp-to-speak-at-catholic-schools |title=Biden's Bishop Will not Permit Him, Even if Elected VP, to Speak at Catholic Schools |last=Westen |first=John-Henry |publisher=[[Catholic Exchange]] |date=August 28, 2008 |accessdate=October 2, 2008}}</ref> Scranton became a flashpoint in the competition for swing-state Catholic voters between the Democratic campaign and liberal Catholic groups, who stressed that other social issues should be considered as much as or more than abortion, and many bishops and conservative Catholics, who maintained abortion was paramount.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/05/us/politics/05catholic.html |title=A Fight Among Catholics Over Which Party Best Reflects Church Teachings |last=Kirkpatrick |first=David D. |work=The New York Times |date=October 4, 2008 |accessdate=October 5, 2008}}</ref> Biden said he believed life begins at conception but would not impose his religious views on others.<ref>{{cite news |first=Kate |last=Phillips |title=As a Matter of Faith, Biden Says Life Begins at Conception |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/08/us/politics/08campaign.html |work=The New York Times |date=September 7, 2008 |accessdate=August 7, 2008 }}</ref> Bishop Saltarelli had previously said of stances like Biden's, "No one today would accept this statement from any public servant: 'I am personally opposed to human slavery and racism but will not impose my personal conviction in the legislative arena.' Likewise, none of us should accept this statement from any public servant: 'I am personally opposed to abortion but will not impose my personal conviction in the legislative arena.'"<ref name="ce082808" />
